results.title: The Bureau head's boyfriend = Nu ju zhang de nan peng you
results.creator_credit: Shanghai Film Studios and Sang Hu
results.brief_description:
Ding Dasen is in love with his girlfriend Zhou Qin, a charming and affectionate young lady who works as the local postal girl. But when her seemingly endless stream of promotions demand more and more of her time, Ding is confronted with a torrent of confusing feelings. Ding goes to visit Zhou, whose father is also a “housewife.” Ding tests her to see what he can get out of the relationship: He refuses to do housework, and wants her to pull strings and grant him favours. But she won’t budge. She has no time for him, and he supposedly needs to work hard to please her. He gets angry, they quarrel, and he leaves.
By the time Miss Zhou has been made Bureau Head of the district’s post office, the once confident and cool Ding Dasen has degenertated into a whining sulky ball of frustration who preoccupies himself with formulating new schemes to make Zhou Qin jealous, or to find quick fixes to make himself more successful than her. As a result, he is easily taken in by the conman Cui Hailong, CEO of the “Space Exploitation Company” to launder money for him. When Cui is not conducting official business entertaining potential investors, he is boiling leather in the back room to sell as medicine. It’s not long before a girl finds a shoe-nail in her medicine and it is time for Cui to move on to a new profession.
Zhou’s high-ranking position doesn’t sit easily with Ding’s Mum either, who justifies Ding’s view of woman’s place in the home. They both think Zhou has too many responsibilities and no time to take care of the household. Here we can also see how Ding’s upbringing according to these strict gender roles has left him totally incapable of taking care of himself. Mum meets butcher girl who is the complete opposite to Zhou. Ding’s mum wants to introduce the local butcher to Ding as a more practical alternative life partner. In a more traditional setup the two mums introduce the two and leave them to hit it off. Butcher girl Zhang immediately starts talking about money, as if discussing love could be substituted for a business negotiation. Ding is romantic and doesn’t appreciate the girl’s world view, who spends every waking hour scrambling for power and status.
Ding’s older sister doesn’t like this new girl either, and seeks out Zhou at the post office. Zhou explains to her why she is always so busy; that she is vested with the heavy responsibilities of mediating not only working practice, but also worker relations: Health, marriage, deaths and quarrels all fall under her jurisdiction. Eventually all is resolved, and both Ding and Zhou are able to compromise to live happily together.
Cultural History of the Film:
The film provides a variety of approaches to the issues relating to shifting gender roles in a rapidly changing society full of opportunity. Amidst all this change, it is also acknowledged that there are many who seek to exploit these changing interpretations and evolving markets. The antagonist of the morally upright approach to living is epitomised by the demonically slick Cui Hailong. Cui is shown to be a man who no longer follows even the most basic moral principles.
With the economic and philosophical reforms of the Chinese system, many people such as Cui, who most likely suffered in their youth during periods of want and famine, were not educated or cared for, and as a result lack the common moral foundation of their peers. This allows them to invent and reinvent themselves, and to take enormous risks without understanding the consequences such actions may have on those around them. The film states explicitly that it is this kind of person that makes China look bad by exporting dangerous and low quality products to make a quick dollar.
Cui recognises that society functions according to many superficial assumptions about power and value, and has learned that quick money can be made by the cunning and able. As Ding thinks back in hindsight to how he and the others were so easily charmed by a man of such dubious character, he says “Cui won me over with a pack of namecards,” a metaphor for the Chinese notion of face, or respectability. However, it is seen as just a matter of time before people like Cui go too far and are caught out by the authorities. The moral of the story is that glamour and power are worthless if the person wielding it does not know how to weild their privelages in an equitable and morally upright fashion.
(3 stars - James Donald; December 15, 2010)

Conservation Information:
Celluloid has some imperfections in the first moments of reels 2 and 4. Audio in good condition.

results.title: The Burden they carry
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Swedish Institute for Cultural Relations, Tom Daly, John Kemeny and Mort Ransen
results.brief_description: Shows one of Sweden’s best known sex educators, Dr Maj-Britt Bergstrom-Wahlan, as she speaks with a class of 8 and 9 year old boys and girls. Later, she holds an informal discussion with an uninhibited group of teenagers, some from Sweden, others from the United States and Great Britain. The film concludes with a poem on the meaning of love and happiness, read by an elderly lady from an old people’s home after she has visited a public exhibition of erotic art.

results.title: The Burden of time
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Legacy”.
Central American civilisation developed quite independently from those of the rest of the world, yet bears striking resemblances to other great civilisations, from the great pyramids it built, and the invention of writing to the relationship of man, earth and the heavens, expressed in ritual and “the mathematics of eternity”. In spite of the disastrous past 500 years of history, the descendants of the Maya and the Aztecs have kept faith with their burden of time, through their shamen, and their blend of Christianity and the old religions, in spite of the pressures of western consumer society.

results.title: The Bupati of Subang: a government official
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
The Bupati is the Government’s chief civilian Administrator in the West Javanese Kabupaten of Subang. His decisions affect the lives of a million people. Assisted by his military background, the Bupati, directly responsible to the Governor of West Java, administers his many responsibilities keeping peace, and harmony in the villages. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary school levels.

results.title: The Bunyip and the Green Ban
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A local report on a residents’ fight to heritage list the Gentle Bunyip, an historic house in Clifton Hill. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: The Bullets of the poets
results.creator_credit: Gittoes and Dalton Productions, Gultha, George Gittoes and Gabrielle Dalton
results.brief_description: For the last decade in Nicaragua, women have been at the frontline of fighting and won the respect of their male companions both as organisers and combatants. Women have brought about this revolutionary change in attitudes by freeing themselves of the stereotype conventions regarding the place of women in war. The six women profiled in the film are remarkable for their sensitivity and the candidness with which they tell their stories. Though they have all experienced the horror of war, none have been hardened. They release their deepest feelings through poetry, and identify more with humanitarian idealism than political ideologies. Filmed entirely on location in Nicaragua.

results.title: The Bulk Link
results.creator_credit: Scope Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The ‘bulk-link’ is the vital bridge from the harvest field to the shipping port- the bulk grain handlers. New techniques in the field, the central storage facilities at the embarkation port have made the bulk link a more economical and efficient process. Photography: Edwin Scragg.

results.title: The Buildings already begun
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover and Bill Pettigrew
results.brief_description: Not everyone agreed that the buildings already begun were worth finishing, but, in spite of opposition, Canada built its imposing Houses of Parliament in Ottawa on the hill above the river. From a rich archive of pictures of the federal Parliament buildings as they developed over the past hundred years, this film creates a vivid sense of being there.

results.title: The Building of Florence Cathedral
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Mary Hoskins
results.brief_description: Shows how, by examining works of art, it is possible to learn much about the society that produced them, with particular reference to the building of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore in renaissance Florence. Commentary by John Larner.

results.title: The Building of Boulder Dam
results.creator_credit: Dowling and Brownell, International Harvester, Pat Dowling and Hobart Brownell
results.brief_description: Shows details of the building of the great structure that dammed the Colorado River forming an extensive lake. Varied activities, incidental to the building of the dam are woven into the story of the film.
